Column Comment.0: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.1: STANDARD METHOD SET IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a set or group ofstandard methods. Often, these would identify a method, consisting of severaldifferent steps, that are included in a typical analysis.
Column Comment.2: PROBLEM OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number that can keep track of theproblems that have arisen in the sample analysis.
Column Comment.3: ANALYSIS ACCURACY TYPE: The kind of accuracy that is indicated, such as theaccuracy of transcription from paper or spreadsheet into the database, or theaccuracy of the readings that a piece of equipment can make, or the impact of acontaminantinto the sample that may render results inaccurate.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: CONFIDENCE TYPE: indicates the confidence that this analysis will give a scientist ifthe problem listed occurs. A method that has a generally high level of confidencemay have a much lower confidence rating in the event the sample is contaminated,for example. In other cases, contaminants may not affect the confidence in theresults.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.7: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.8: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.9: PROBLEM DESCRIPTION: A narrative description about the problem that has arisenin the sample analysis.
Column Comment.10: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM RESULT: The type of consequence that wasthe outcome of the problem described. For example, results may be inaccurate, or atest may be destroyed, or results may show anomalous values.
Column Comment.11: PROBLEM SEVERITY: Narrative remarks about the severity of the problem,including how serious the impact is on the data quality.
Column Comment.12: REFERENCE ANALYSIS PROBLEM TYPE: This reference list contains a list of thevalid problems that can and are associated with laboratory analysis. Problems mayrelate to equipment calibration errors, sample contamination, incorrect proceduresused,technical error etc.
Column Comment.13: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.14: PROBLEM RESOLUTION METHOD DESCRIPTION: Narrative comments about howthe problem with the data were resolved.
Column Comment.15: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.16: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.17: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.18: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.19: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.20: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.21: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.22: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.23: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
